modules.description: The module offers low-level control over asynchronous I/O operations through direct use of uring, supporting both confined and unconfined paths, as well as absolute file references. It manages a fixed buffer allocated at runtime, which may fail under resource constraints. Operations include initializing and managing I/O requests, handling completion events, and controlling execution flow. Examples include submitting read/write operations, monitoring completion queues, and managing buffer sizes dynamically.

Reads from and writes to files, establishes network connections, and executes blocking or CPU-bound tasks in a concurrent manner. It operates on file descriptors, sockets, and asynchronous channels, supporting both direct and effectful programming styles. Use it to build high-performance network servers or to manage I/O operations in a structured, non-blocking way.

provides low-level asynchronous I/O control using Linux's io_uring, enabling direct management of I/O requests and completion events. It supports confined and unconfined I/O paths, file references, and dynamic buffer adjustments. Key operations include submitting read/write operations, monitoring completion queues, and managing execution flow. It allows precise control over I/O resources, such as handling large data transfers or custom buffer management.
